title: Nightmare loss to Miami still stings for Virginia Tech as rematch looms
text:
Nightmare loss to Miami still stings for Virginia Tech as rematch looms Virginia Tech's Frank Beamer discusses last season's loss to Miami 
Beamer on his team getting getting "kicked" by Miami "like we don't get kicked very much" 
Beamer on his team getting getting "kicked" by Miami "like we don't get kicked very much" Norm Wood Contact Reporter nwood@dailypress.com #Hokies coach Frank Beamer recalls last season's loss to Miami as worst his team has been "kicked" in a while 
BLACKSBURG — Isaiah Ford had never heard such a vitriolic response from fans in a place he called home. It’s something he’ll never forget. 
In his fifth home game wearing Virginia Tech’s colors, Ford was witness last season to a merciless vocal symphony from a disgruntled fan base during Tech’s 30-6 loss to Miami. Embarrassed and stunned, Ford learned from the experience. 
“It was awful,” said Ford, a sophomore wide receiver who leads Tech with 28 catches for 421 yards and paces the Atlantic Coast Conference with six touchdown catches. “That was the first time I ever got booed at a home game in my whole career, so that isn’t a feeling that I ever want to feel again.” 
He’s not the only Tech player or coach to come away from last season’s Thursday night disaster in Lane Stadium against the Hurricanes with his pride hurt. 
Coming off its most impressive win of the season last Friday in a 28-13 victory against North Carolina State, Tech (3-3, 1-1 Atlantic Coast Conference) is back in the thick of the Coastal Division race, but a Saturday trip to play Miami and its potent passing attack is on the horizon. 
The 2015 Virginia Tech football season in photos. 
It remains to be seen which quarterback will command Tech’s offense — Michael Brewer or Brenden Motley. Brewer still is recovering from a broken collarbone he sustained Sept. 7 in Tech’s season-opening loss to No. 1 Ohio State. 
Tech associate head coach and running backs coach Shane Beamer said Monday that Brewer hadn’t been medically cleared to play in games as of Sunday’s team meetings, but he was slated to be re-evaluated by team doctors Monday afternoon and Tuesday. Brewer returned to full practice participation last week, but wasn’t cleared for Friday’s game against N.C. State. Virginia Tech's Isaiah Ford talks about remembering Miami loss 
Ford on recalling the feeling of last season's loss to Miami, but not letting it affect play this Saturday 
Ford on recalling the feeling of last season's loss to Miami, but not letting it affect play this Saturday See more videos 
In Brewer’s place, Motley has provided a larger spark than first expected, completing 55.7 percent of his passes for 1,019 yards, 10 touchdowns and five interceptions, and adding 194 yards and three rushing touchdowns while posting a 3-2 record as a starter. 
If Motley starts at Miami, whose win last season represented the largest margin of victory by a Tech opponent in Lane Stadium under Beamer since the Hokies’ 41-7 loss to Florida State in 1989, it would be his first ACC road start. 
Miami’s 364 rushing yards against Tech last season, the most the Hokies have surrendered in Coach Frank Beamer’s 29 seasons in Blacksburg, already has been a topic of conversation this week around Tech’s football offices and locker room. 
“Didn’t throw it very much,” Frank Beamer said regarding Miami quarterback Brad Kaaya, who completed 7 of 16 passes for 92 yards and a touchdown last season as a freshman at Tech. “Didn’t need to. 
“Last year, they just came in here and kicked us like we don’t get kicked very much.” 
Though Miami (3-2, 0-1) is coming off a 29-24 loss to No. 12 FSU, the Hurricanes have successfully moved the ball this season in different ways than it did last season. Miami is 12th in the ACC this season in rushing offense (143.8 yards per game), but Kaaya’s throwing is now the focal point of the offense. 
Gone to the NFL is running back Duke Johnson, who ran for 249 yards last season at Tech — the most ever by an opposing running back in Lane Stadium. Gus Edwards, who gained 115 rushing yards last season at Tech, is out for the season with a foot injury. 
“I mean, they were busting runs for 8 yards a pop,” said Tech defensive tackle Luther Maddy, who watched last season’s game from the sideline with a knee injury. “Terrible job up front on defense … so I think we still have a chip on our shoulder just being embarrassed from last year.” 
This season, Kaaya is leading the top passing offense in the ACC (309.8 yards per game) and 18th-best in the nation out of 127 Football Bowl Subdivision programs. 
He’s completed 60.8 percent of his passes for 1,499 yards, eight touchdowns and one interception, and leads the ACC in total offense (292.4 yards per game). Against FSU, he completed 29 of 49 passes for 405 yards and three touchdowns. 
“He can throw it,” Frank Beamer said. “You can tell he’s very much in charge, too, and he’s got some explosive receivers.” 
A trio of Miami receivers — Rashawn Scott (29 catches for 415 yards and two touchdowns), Herb Waters (19 catches for 299 yards) and Stacy Coley (the ACC’s Receiver of the Week after catching seven passes for 139 yards and a touchdown at FSU) — present a tough matchup for Tech’s young secondary, which has worked through growing pains to spearhead the nation’s 11th-best passing defense (150.5 yards per game). 
While Tech waits to see which quarterback will direct its passing game, it appears to have found the No. 1 option it has been seeking in the backfield. Travon McMillian, who had 11 carries for 96 yards and a touchdown against N.C. State, again will be Tech’s starting tailback at Miami, which is 12th in the ACC in total defense (383 yards per game). 
“Our backs were to the wall, and our coaches and players, I thought, did a tremendous job,” Frank Beamer said of his team’s win against N.C. State. “Sometimes coaches get lost in that, but I tell them that’s when they coach their best … that’s when coaching makes a difference. “Anyone can coach when things are silky smooth and going well, but that’s when you find out who the good coaches are — when it’s a little rough and people are doubting you and not many good things are being said about you.”
